Here, one should further contemplate: For what reason did the World-Honored One separately speak of the faculties?
The entire internal realm and one part of the dharmas, by the meaning of predominance, are separately spoken of as faculties, because they obtain predominance in each matter.
Although the meaning of predominance is possessed by all dharmas, only the most predominant are established as faculties.
Who is most predominant with respect to whom?
Verse:
The five faculties have predominance in four matters, the four faculties have predominance in two kinds,
The five and eight have predominance in the defiled and pure, respectively.
Treatise:
Not all faculties have the most predominant function in one matter.
The five faculties such as the eye each have the function of predominance in four matters: 1. Adorning the body, 2. Nourishing the body, 3. Producing consciousness, etc., 4. Unique matters.
As for adorning the body, it means that if any one of the five faculties is lacking, the body is ugly.

As for guiding and nourishing the body, it means that based on seeing and hearing, one can avoid dangerous situations, and because one can enjoy material food, the three of smell, taste, and touch all become material food. As a verse says:
Just as a person with clear eyes can avoid present dangers,
In the world, there are wise people who can avoid future suffering and evil.
The learned can understand the Dharma, the learned can avoid wrongdoing,
The learned abandon what is meaningless, the learned attain nirvana.
The body depends on food for existence, life depends on food for preservation, after eating, it makes the mind
pleasantly comfortable and secure.
As for producing consciousness, it means giving rise to the five consciousnesses and their associated mental factors, because the clarity or obscurity of the faculties that are their supports varies.
As for the unique function, it means apprehending its own object, seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, and distinguishing the object.
Some say that the eye and ear have a dominant influence in the production of the physical body and the Dharma body, respectively. The first two gÄthÄs are evidence for this.
Some say that both the eye and ear can protect the two bodies, the physical and the Dharma body, because associating with good people and listening to the true Dharma are each a dominant influence.
The female, male, life, and mind faculties each have a dominant influence in two things.
As for the two dominant influences of the female and male faculties, one is the difference in sentient beings, and the second is the difference in discrimination.

As for the difference in sentient beings, in the beginning of the eon, the forms of sentient beings were all the same. After the two faculties were produced, there were distinctions in the forms of females and males.
As for the difference in discrimination, there are distinctions in the arrangement of gait, speech, breasts, hair buns, and so forth.
Some say that because of the difference in courage and fear, it is called the difference in sentient beings;
because of the difference in clothing and adornments, it is called the difference in discrimination.

Some say: It is said that it has predominance with regard to both defiled and pure realms, because it generates uninterrupted karma and severs wholesome roots in the two disciplines of non-restraint, which is called having predominance with regard to the defiled realm.

Because it can receive discipline, enter the path, attain the fruits, and be free from desires, it is called having predominance with regard to the pure realm. Eunuchs and so forth do not have such things.

As for the predominance of the life faculty in the two, it means that because of life, the faculties and distinctions among the faculties are established. Because of this, they exist; without this, they do not exist.
Or, in the realm of formlessness, there must be the life faculty in order for the place of rebirth to be determined.
Because it gives rise to wholesome or defiled minds of its own realm, or gives rise to other minds, it does not end life.
As for the predominance of the mind faculty in the two, it means being able to continue subsequent existence and being able to freely follow.

Because it is said in the scriptures. The eight faculties of faith, etc., are dominant in purification, as a scripture says:
Our holy disciples are endowed with the ramparts of faith, the power of diligence, the defense of mindfulness, the concentration of the mind, the sword of wisdom, and so forth.
Because the last three faculties are included in this passage, they are dominant in the category of purification.

If something is established as a faculty because it is dominant, then the two dharmas of feeling and conceptualization have a dominant function among the passions of craving and views, and conceptualization should be established as a faculty just as feeling is.
Also, the passions have a dominant function in the destruction of good dharmas, etc., and should constitute the substance of a faculty.
Also, the faculties are established because they are most excellent. NirvÄá¹‡a is most excellent of all dharmas. Why is it not established as a faculty?
KÄpila says that speech, hands, feet, and the anus should also be established as faculties, because they have predominance in speaking, grasping, moving, and discarding.
Such things should not be established as faculties, because the accepted definition of a faculty is as follows.
A verse says:
The mind and its support, its distinctions, its abiding, its defilements,
Its provisions, its purification, and its liberation - the faculties are established based on these.
The treatise says:
The support of the mind refers to the six faculties such as the eye. These six internal bases are the basis of sentient beings.
Their distinctions are due to the male and female faculties.
Moreover, due to the life faculty, they abide for a period of time. They become defiled

due to the five faculties of feeling. Their provisions for purification are due to the five faculties such as faith. They attain purification due to the last three faculties. Based on these, the purpose of establishing faculties is fully accomplished. Conceptualization and so forth should not be established as faculties.
Among the afflictions, craving is the most serious fault, so only feeling is established as its faculty.
The fault of craving is heavier, because a scripture says:
Craving is the cause of the generation of the six sense bases.

Also, conceptualization is not the cause of the generation of the passions. Other causes generate the inverted views, and false conceptualization continues to exist, held by them. It cannot be destroyed without the correct antidote, and therefore it is said that conceptualization is the cause of those views.
Feeling is the cause of craving, and both are of two kinds.
The fault of feeling is heavier, because it is the cause of the passions and because it is the cause of both. Therefore it is established as a separate faculty.

translated: Conceptualization is not established as a root because it is overwhelmed by other dharmas, that is, good conceptualization is overwhelmed by correct insight, and defiled conceptualization is overwhelmed by the inversions. Because it is not dominant, it is not established as a root.
Also, the various passions are not dominant, because feeling is dominant among them. Therefore only feeling can be established as a root.
How can something that harms the good group of dharmas and destroys the business of pleasant results be established as a root? It is inferior, contemptible, and defiled.
because the faculties are the dominant real entities of the world.
Also, although nirvÄá¹‡a is superior to all dharmas, it is not established as a faculty because it causes the cessation of all faculties.
It is like the destruction of all pots, which is not the substance of a non-pot.
Also, the organs of speech, etc., are not called faculties, because of the errors of indefiniteness, confusion, and excess.
The error of indefiniteness is this: What is the organ of speech among the organs of speech?
That which is called the organ of speech is named the organ of speech because it is the instrument of speech. This is the tongue.

If that is so, then such dharmas as applied thought and sustained thought, and the winds that cause the activity of speech, should also be established as faculties, because they can cause speech.ğŸ”½This is because applied thought, sustained thought, etc., cause the utterance of speech in dependence on the lips, teeth, palate, throat, etc., and not just on the tongue, because there is no different cause.

Also, because applied thought, sustained thought, etc., are the superior causes of the utterance of speech. Also, because such things as the hands, armpits, flutes, strings, and breath, etc., are all able to cause the utterance of speech, you should not establish only the tongue as the organ of speech.
If you say that one understands form because of words, and therefore the eye should not be established as a faculty, this is not reasonable.
Even though blind people hear the word form, they do not understand the characteristics of blue, etc.
The hand should not be called a faculty in grasping, because the mouth, etc., can also grasp things.
The foot should not be called a faculty in locomotion, because snakes, fish, etc., move about without feet.
The anus should not be called a faculty in excretion, because the mouth, etc., can also excrete.

The error of confusion is that the faculties established by them would be confused, because the mouth both grasps and excretes, and the hand and foot both have the function of locomotion. There is this kind of error of confusion.
The error of excess is that the faculties established by them would be unlimited.
If the tongue faculty is different from the speech faculty, then one should admit that the nose faculty is different from the breathing faculty, because the tongue speaks and the nose breathes.

If something is a faculty because it has some function with regard to something else, then the throat, teeth, lips, stomach, etc., should be faculties, because they have predominance with regard to swallowing, chewing, holding, etc.
Or, since all causes have predominance with regard to the production of their own effects, all causes should be faculties.
Therefore, the theory of KÄpila that the tongue and sex organs are faculties should not be accepted, like the theories of children.
The meaning of faculty and the reason for establishing faculties have been explained. Now we will explain the individual natures of the faculties.
Among them, the eye, etc., up to the male faculty, have already been distinguished in this chapter, namely, the five kinds of pure form that are the basis of consciousness, called the eye, etc.
The female and male faculties are established as distinctions within the body.
The life faculty is by nature not associated with the mind, so it will be discussed in the section on the non-associated compositional factors.
Faith, etc., are by nature mental factors, so they will be discussed in the section on mental factors.
The five feelings such as pleasure and the three pure faculties have no other place where they can be discussed, therefore they should now be explained.
Verse:
The body's lack of pleasure is called suffering, and this very pleasure is called happiness.
And the mental pleasure in the third concentration is called joy in other places.
Mental lack of pleasure is called sorrow, and there is no distinction between the two in the middle of equanimity.
The paths of seeing, cultivation, and no-more-learning are established based on the nine faculties, and three faculties are established.
Discussion:
The body refers to bodily feelings because they rely on physical faculties, and they are the feelings associated with the five consciousnesses.
What is called lack of pleasure has the meaning of harm. Among the feelings of touch experienced along with the five consciousnesses, that which can harm is called the faculty of suffering.
What is called pleasure has the meaning of benefit. Among the feelings of touch experienced along with the five consciousnesses, that which can benefit is called the faculty of happiness.
In the first concentration, the happiness experienced along with the three consciousnesses is also included here, because its type is the same.

The feeling of satisfaction and comfort associated with mental consciousness in the third trance state is also called the faculty of pleasure, because there is no other feeling in that state. The feeling of satisfaction and comfort associated with mental consciousness is called the faculty of pleasure.
The feeling of satisfaction and comfort associated with mental consciousness is of two kinds. In the third trance state, it is called pleasure, because one is free from craving for joy.
In the three lower trance states, it is called the faculty of joy, because there is craving for joy.
These two feelings of satisfaction and comfort are the same in their meaning of comfort and benefit. What is the difference in their modes of activity that they are distinguished as joy and pleasure?
They differ because of the difference in their modes of activity.ğŸ”½If the feeling of satisfaction and comfort is calm and quiet in its mode of activity, it is called the faculty of pleasure.
If the feeling of satisfaction and comfort is gross and agitated in its mode of activity, it is called the faculty of joy.
Or, the faculty of pleasure is superior in its comfort and benefit, while the faculty of joy is not so in comfort and benefit.
For this reason, the pleasure of the third trance state is said by the sages to be a state of addiction.
Associated with mental consciousness, it injures and distresses the mind, and is called the faculty of sorrow.
The above four faculties of feeling have been established on the basis of the differences in the modes of activity of feelings of pleasure, etc., in relation to body and mind.
The two feelings of indifference are not distinguished, because the meaning of indifference is neither pleasure nor pain, and it is called the faculty of indifference.
In what kind of feeling is this indifference subsumed?
It is said that this feeling is found in both body and mind.
Why are pleasure and pain each divided into two, while neither-pleasure-nor-pain is established as only one faculty?
Because it is found in body and mind without distinction.
That is, pleasure and pain in the mind are mostly agitated, but when pleasure and pain are in the body, they are calm and stable.
Neither-pleasure-nor-pain, whether in the body or in the mind, is without difference in mode of activity and is only calm and stable.
Moreover, pleasure and pain in the mind are mostly born of discrimination, but this is not so in the body, because they arise through the power of objects. They also arise in arhats and others.
Indifference in the body and mind is both without discrimination, and it arises spontaneously in a neutral mode of activity.
Moreover, the two feelings of pain and pleasure occur in the body and in the mind, and their modes of activity differ in regard to enemies and friends.
The feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant occurs in the body and in the mind, and its mode of activity is the same in regard to a neutral object.
Therefore, pain and pleasure are each divided into two, and the feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant is established as only one faculty.
The nature of the faculties of pleasure, etc., have been explained. The three pure faculties should be explained next.
Their natures cannot be explained separately, one by one. They should be established in general, in dependence on the three paths.

The mind, pleasure, joy, and indifference, and the five faculties beginning with faith, these nine are the three pure faculties in the three paths. That is, the nine dharmas of mind, etc., in the path of insight are the essence of the faculty of having attained the understanding of that not yet understood, because they evolve with the mode of activity of that which is to be understood.

If they are in the path of cultivation, the nine dharmas of mind, etc., are the essence of the second faculty of having attained understanding, because in order to eliminate the remaining propensities, one must understand again and again the objects that have been understood.

The nine faculties of mind, etc., in the path of no-more-learning are the essence of the third faculty of perfect knowledge. It is called perfect knowledge because it knows itself and because the habit of knowing becomes a nature.
Or it is called perfect knowledge because it can protect knowledge.
These nine faculties are associated and form this matter. Therefore, the eight faculties of mind, etc., are also called perfect knowledge.

translated: Thus, although the names of the faculties are twenty-two, the actual faculties are only seventeen, because the two faculties of female and male are included in the body faculty, and because the three pure faculties are included in the nine faculties.
Thus, the different essences of the faculties have been explained. Next, the distinctions in the meanings of various categories will be discussed.
Among these twenty-two faculties, how many are contaminated and how many are uncontaminated?
Verse:
Only the last three are uncontaminated. The faculties of form, life, and sorrow and suffering,
Should be known as only contaminated. The remaining nine faculties are both.
Treatise:
The last three faculties mentioned above are only pure, and are called stainless, because defilement and impurity are synonymous.
The seven material faculties are called material because they are categorized as form. Life, grief, and pain are only impure.

The nine faculties that are both are the three pure faculties, i.e., the mental faculty, pleasure, and satisfaction, which are called pure, and the other nine faculties, i.e., the five such as faith and the three faculties such as the faculty of knowing and seeing, which are called impure.
Some say that the five such as faith are only pure.
This is unreasonable, because the World Honored One said,

If I had not fully understood the five faculties such as faith as to their origination, disappearance, satisfaction, unsatisfactoriness, and escape, I could not have transcended the world of gods, humans, and asuras. He said this in detail, but the dharmas are not pure.
We should investigate in this order.
Also, before the Buddha turned the wheel of the Dharma, he first used the eye of a Buddha to observe the differences in the sharp, middling, and dull faculties of sentient beings in the world.
This extensive discernment is like the ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma.
Thus far, the contaminated and uncontaminated have been explained.
Among the twenty-two faculties, how many are karmic results and how many are not karmic results?
Verse:
Life is only karmic result, and the last eight are not karmic results.
Form, mind, the other four feelings, each has two aspects.
Treatise:
First, among these faculties, only the one faculty of life is definitely a karmic result.
How can this life be without discrimination?
Because the life faculty of the fixed result is not a karmic result.

Thus, this life faculty is also a karmic result. Because it is said by the sages.

Some say that by the power of the ultimate samÄdhi, one attracts the life span that was to be experienced as indeterminate retribution in a previous life and makes it be experienced now. Others say that the power of the ultimate samÄdhi attracts the remaining results of past karma.
The faculty of sorrow and the last eight faculties, such as faith, are not retribution because they are morally good.
A scripture says,
There is action whose retribution is to be experienced as sorrow. This is said with reference to the associated feeling.
To say that action is to be experienced as sorrow is not erroneous, just as it is said that contact is to be experienced as pleasure.
How do we know with certainty that sorrow is not retribution?
Because it does not continue to exist when one is free from craving.
Retribution does not do this, and therefore sorrow is not retribution.
How do we know with certainty that sorrow does not continue to exist when one is free from craving?
Because sorrow is the result of the outflow of ignorance. Because arhats and others have eliminated all ignorance, they have no sorrow, because they have no characteristics of hatred.
Because arhats who are free from craving for the desire realm have already eliminated all the calamities and troubles of the desire realm, they also have no enemies or those they dislike.
Moreover, because their mental continuum is filled with joy, those free from craving for the desire realm do not experience sorrow.
Therefore we know that the faculty of sorrow transcends the dharmas of retribution, while the other faculties are of both kinds. This meaning is already established by implication.
That is, the seven material faculties, the mental faculty, and the four feelings other than sorrow, each of the twelve are of both kinds.
If the seven material faculties are nourished, they are not retribution, while the rest are all retribution.

If the mental faculty and the four feelings are wholesome, defiled, deportment, craftsmanship, or transformation, according to their respective cases, they are also not retribution, while the rest are all retribution.
Thus we have explained what is retribution, etc.
Among the twenty-two faculties, how many have retribution and how many have no retribution?
Verse:
Sorrow definitely has retribution. The first eight and the last three have none.
The other faculties, such as faith, are each of two kinds.
The treatise says:
It should be understood that the faculty of sorrow definitely has retribution.
The word definitely indicates that it is only retribution and not non-retribution. It is excluded because it is indeterminate and uncontaminated.
The first eight faculties, such as the eye, and the last three, this eleven faculties definitely have no retribution, because the eight are indeterminate and the three are uncontaminated.

The remaining faculties are both, and the meaning is already established by implication. That is, the faculty of mind and the other four, such as faith, and so on, also includes the four faculties such as zeal, these eleven are each of two kinds.
If the faculties of mind, joy, pleasure, and indifference are wholesome or unwholesome contaminated, they have retribution. If they are indeterminate or uncontaminated, they have no retribution.
If the faculty of suffering is wholesome or unwholesome, it has retribution. If it is indeterminate, it has no retribution.
If the five faculties such as faith are contaminated, they have retribution. If they are uncontaminated, they have no retribution.
Thus, those that have retribution and so on have been explained.
Among the twenty-two faculties, how many are wholesome, how many are unwholesome, and how many are indeterminate?
Verse:
The last eight faculties are only wholesome, and the faculty of sorrow is both wholesome and unwholesome.
The mind and the other three feelings are of three kinds, and the first eight are only indeterminate.
Commentary:

The five faculties such as faith and the three pure faculties are exclusively wholesome. The faculty of sorrow is only of the nature of both wholesome and unwholesome. The mind and the four feelings are all of three natures. The eight faculties such as the eye are only indeterminate.
Thus, the wholesome, unwholesome, etc. have been explained.
Among the twenty-two faculties, how many are bound to the desire realm, how many are bound to the form realm, and how many are bound to the formless realm?
Verse:
The desire, form, and formless realms, in order, exclude the last three,
And also the female and male faculties, sorrow and suffering, and the rest of the form realm, joy and pleasure.
Commentary:
The desire realm excludes the last three pure faculties, because those three faculties are only unattached. It is understood that the desire realm is bound to the remaining nineteen faculties.

The realm of form is like the realm of desire in that it lacks the three pure faculties, and it also lacks the faculties of female, male, sorrow, and suffering. It should be understood that fifteen faculties are also found in the realm of form.
The faculties of female and male are absent in the realm of form because one is already free of sexual desire and the sexual organs are useless.
There is an opinion that they are absent because the body is ugly.
This opinion is not correct, because the sexual organs are hidden and not ugly. The Buddha placed them in the category of male.
As a scripture says,

The faculty of suffering is absent in the realm of form because there is no injury there.
Suffering is the result of the retribution of karma that injures.
Some say that this is because the body there is extremely pure and subtle.
The faculty of sorrow is absent there, because there is no one there who is an enemy or a hateful person, and because the continuum of being is moistened by samÄdhi.
Some say that the realm of form is endowed with the knowledge of the separation from passions, and sorrow is the result of the outflow of ignorance.

The formless realm is like the realm of form, but in addition to the three pure faculties, the faculties of female and male, and sorrow, it also lacks the faculties of pleasure, joy, and the five roots of consciousness. It should be understood that the remaining eight faculties are found in the formless realm.
This concludes the discussion of the faculties that are found in the realm of desire, etc.
How many of the twenty-two faculties are eliminated by insight into the truths? How many are eliminated by cultivation? How many are not eliminated?
A verse says:
The three beginning with mind and the three beginning with sorrow are eliminated by insight and cultivation.
Nine are eliminated by cultivation alone. Five are eliminated by cultivation or not eliminated.
The treatise says:
The three faculties of mind, joy, and pleasure are each of three kinds.
The faculty of sorrow is eliminated by insight and cultivation, because it is not pure.

The seven material faculties, life, and suffering are to be eliminated by cultivation only, because the material faculties are not uncontaminated, because they are not born of the sixth, i.e., the manas, and because they are not pure.
The five faculties of faith, etc., are either to be eliminated by cultivation or not to be eliminated, because they are good and contaminated or pure.
The last three faculties are not to be eliminated, because they are pure and free from error.
However, a scripture says:
â€œYou should know that the noble path is like a boat or a raft, for one should abandon even the Dharma, let alone non-Dharma.â€
This is not eliminated by the two paths of insight and cultivation, but is abandoned when one enters the state of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder. Abandoning it is called eliminating it.
We have explained the differences in the meanings of the various categories. We now discuss the first acquisition of the faculties with retribution.
How many faculties with retribution are first acquired in what realm?
Why do we ask about the first acquisition of faculties with retribution? To prevent the idea that a nondefiled mind can link up with rebirth.
A verse says:
In the desire realm, in the womb, in the first two birth processes, one first acquires two faculties with retribution.
In the other birth processes, six, seven, or eight. In the form realm, six. Above, only the life faculty.ğŸ”½The verse says,
The treatise says:
In the initial stage of rebirth, those born from wombs, eggs, or moisture in the desire realm only obtain two matured faculties, the body and life faculties.
Mentioning womb, egg, and moisture birth reveals that this excludes apparitional birth, because the faculties of form in apparitional birth do not gradually arise.
Here, in discussing maturation, the mind and indifference faculties are not mentioned, because at that time they are definitely defiled and not matured.
At that time, one also obtains the faculties such as faith, but because they are not matured, they are not mentioned here.
This is discussed in terms of apparitional birth, not in terms of the three kinds of birth.
Although in the kalala stage one obtains the dharmas that are matured from form, etc., their substance is not a faculty, and therefore they are not mentioned here.
In the initial stage of apparitional birth, one obtains six, seven, or eight faculties. Those without form obtain six.
Like at the beginning of the eon, the six are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and life faculties.
Those with one form obtain seven, like the gods, etc.
Those with two forms obtain eight. Evil destinies may have apparitional birth with two forms.
